header.title: Men - The forgotten gender | Deepika Bhardwaj | TEDxIIFTDelhi
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Deepika talks about the how men in the Indian society are suffering due to the draconian Indian Penal Code which is made for the protection of women but ignores men and their issues. She addresses the Indian Dowry Act from the perspective of men. Deepika talks of men who are victimised and sustematically abused by laws that are made for women but are abused to victimise men. Deepika Narayan Bhardwaj is a Journalist, Anchor and a Documentary Filmmaker. Her first documentary ‘Gramin Dak Sevak' was Jeevika All Asia Livelihood Film Festival 2009, student film winner. Her second documentary ‘Youth Count' was broadcast on India's leading News channel NDTV 24x7. Her third project ‘Garima' was a commissioned, short documentary film by USAID and Counterpart International. A software engineer turned Journalist, she was one of the ten media professionals selected from around the world for ‘Future Media Leaders Course' conducted by Thomson Foundation, UK. She is currently making documentary called 'Martyrs of Marriage' which is a commentary on the issue of Men's right and abuse of one-sided gender centric laws in the Indian Penal Code. This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx

IPC 498A पुरुषों पर अत्याचार को लीगलाइज करता है। यह कानून एक लीगल क्राइम है समाज के स्ट्रक्चर पर जो अपने उद्देश्य की पूर्ति के बदले ढांचे को कमजोर करने में ज्यादा योगदान करता है।

मैं सबसे पहले तथाकथित स्त्रीवादियों को एड्रेस करते हुए कहना चाहूँगा, दहेज- निःसन्देह निंदनीय परम्परा है। पर "निन्दनीय" की आड़ में इस परम्परा को नजरअंदाज जिस किसी भी कोशिस से की जा रही है वो न पुरूष के हित मे है न महिला के। दहेज के विरोध में हर आवाज महिला के सशक्तिकरन के लिए सबसे ज्यादा जरूरी, सम्पत्ति के अधिकार पर आश्चयर्जनक रूप से चुप हो जाती है। दहेज़,एक निन्दनीय परम्परा, उस टाइम-स्पेस में महिलाओं के सम्पत्ति के अधिकार को सुनिश्चित करने का एक तरीका भर था। दहेज़ विरोधी माँग जबतक सम्पत्ति के अधिकार को समायोजित नही करता, ये खोखला ही रहेगा।
तथाकथित स्त्रीवादी गरीबी के जेन्डर स्पेसिफिक बताते हैं क्योंकि महिलाओ के पास कोई सम्पत्ति नही, शायद स्त्रीवादयो ने इसपर काम किया होता तो महिलाएँ गरीब न होती।
ये महिलाएं, जो घर मे बैठकर न कुचनकरते हुए भी, बिना किसी मूवेबल/इममूवेबल सम्पत्ति के बस रहने खाने का ही नही बल्कि एक आसान से परिरुण जिंदगी का निर्वाह कर लेती हैं, ओर गरीब रहते हुए भी ये सम्भव है, इस तकनीकी पर हमारे नीति-निर्माताओं को अध्ययन करना चाहिये की कैसे एक गरीब इतने ऐस आराम से, गरीब रह कर भी, जीवन-यापन कर सकता है।
खैर, ये अलग बात है।



IPC 498A पर ध्यान से देखें तो साफ पता चलता है ये कानून किसी हड़बड़ी में बना था। एक गुनाह जो हिनियस न होकर भी नन-बेलेबल था। और इस क्राइम में एविडेन्स कलेक्ट करने की जरूरत बिल्कुल नही थी, एफआईआर के साथ ही अरेस्ट करना होता था। सब अरेस्ट होते थे, 2 से 6 महीने के बच्चे भी अरेस्ट हुए हैं। 3000 किमी दूर रह रही ननद ने, मान लिया, मानसिक प्रताड़ना किया बहुरानी का, पर ये 6 महीने का बच्चा भी!! 
महिलाओं की सुरक्षा के लिए बनाए गए इस कानून न महिलाओं को ही ज्यादा असुरक्षित किया। 

कुछ सर्वे में पता चला कि इस धारा का दुरुपियोग इस हद तक बढ़ गया है कि 53% केस गलत साबित हुए हैं। आधे से ज्यादा!!


भले 100 दोषी छूट जाएं, एक निर्दोष को सजा नही मिलनी चाहिए। इस देश में कानून व्यवस्था शायद इसी गोल्डन लाइन को फॉलो करता आया है अबतक। लेकिन 53% फेक रेट से जा रही न्याय व्यवस्था अब भी खुद को न्यायव्यवस्था कह पा रही है ये देख बेशर्मी के हद की जो ऊँचाई मैंने सोची थी अपने कल्पना में, बढ़ गई है। न्यायालय के बेशर्मी की ये ऊँचाई अकल्पनीय है।

एक जेन्डर के सशक्तिकरण की बेवकूफ़ाना कोशिस ने समाज को ही कमज़ोर कर दिया है।

I have been reading the comments and as expected they are quite toxic. Allow me to pump some objective truth into some of the idiots among us. Women and men are important. BOTH important to life in every way. NO one person is better or worse than the other because of his or her genitals. Every single person has the right to life, safety and freedoms that will give them a comfortable life. Things like rape or other issues that violate the rights of any human are absolutely wrong and there should be appropriate justice. Everyone has the right to justice and to be heard. That being said, history has shown us that there was a trend of misogyny which lead to the establishment of feminism ie: a movement pushing for the equality of both genders instead of the notion that women were overall inferior to men. Of course there are people who have made Feminism into a terrible misandrist movement and then the more ignorant ones who let the 'bad apples' spoil the lot thereby allowing Feminism to become something horrendously inaccurate and far from what it was intended to be by believing and emphasizing on the messages preached by misandrists claiming to be feminists...but anyway, Feminism is still an important movement as it truly aims for the equivalence of women and men not domination over or neglect of the other. In all honesty, I do not think anyone should object to a movement that promotes the idea of equality for the human race turning a blind eye to something we are born with without choice - our genitalia. If the word "Feminism" alone triggers you then you ought to educate yourself on its true definition and purpose rather than the perverted version by misandrists and other "humans" who have muddied the term out of hatred. I am yet to see the day where humans can be heard and treated as humans rather than female or male with consequential biases stemming from stereotypes. Stereotypes are absolutely worthless and do very little in the way of progression. Human beings, please learn to love yourselves and your neighbours based on who they are as a living being rather than judging, abusing and stereotyping on trivial things li ke gend er, sex, preferences and weak social constructs that bring more hatred, disharmony, limitations and conflict to life. It does not take any God or great force of nature to teach you the value of human life...if it does, then you are beyond repair. Know better, do better.

India seems to have had a worse problem with exaggerations in recent years. According to the Indian National Crime Records Bureau, in 2015 there were 34,651 rapes in 2015. Involving less than 0.006% of males in India. But this figure tends to be normally inflated due to new definitions including trivial incidents. So let's look at what rape is (in India). Consider a detailed six-month study of all 583 cases of alleged rape that came up before district courts in Delhi in 2013 (search for, thehindu+data+the-many-shades-of-rape-cases-in-delhi): 20% of the cases were wound up because the complainant did not appear or turned hostile. Of the cases fully tried, over 40% dealt with consensual sex, usually involving the elopement of a young couple and the girl's parents subsequently charging the boy with rape. Another 25% dealt with 'breach of promise to marry'. Of the 162 remaining cases, men preying on young children in slums was the mos t common type of offence.' And of these 162, the accused was known to the complainant in all but 12 cases. Consensu al sex on a false promise/pretext of marriage is often reported as rape and then recorded by the police as such. In November 2014, the Mumbai police commissioner reported that 71.9% of rapes reported that year were related to consens ual sex that did not lead to marriage. In India, it is perfectly legitimate to pursue such cases. Recall the 0.006% of males in India figure; the percentage of seriously mentally ill males in India would be more than 10 times that figure, so what proportion of rapes would involve mentally ill perpetrators? This is ignored. Logic is ignored when feminist propaganda is concerned. The video on this page is feminist propaganda produced by feminists appealing for government grants.

You're confusing " sex" and "gender". They are two different things. "Sex" is the parts you are born with. "Gender" is the "women wear high heels and dresses and men w ear black shoes and a tuxedo at the wedding" sort of stuff.
Yet if gender is entirely a social construct, there would be no people believing their gender does not align with thei r sex, thus wishing to take hormones.

What I think you're asking is why do some people g et Gender Reassignment Surgery if gender is a social construct? Just so you're aware, only about a third of "transgender" people get GRS. Just be cause "se x" and "gender" are different ideas, doesn't meant they have to suddenly be completely different things. Gender is a much bigger term that includes sex, but is not even close to limit ed to just sex: Sex: penis = male vagin a = femal e Gender (a woman - circa 1950s) wears dresses = female knows flower arrangement = female stays home with the kids = female rebuilt a tractor by hand = male does not shave armpits = male vagina = female wears a lot of pink = female

Gender = the generally observed intrinsic differences in risk aversion, types of play, learning styles, communication methods, etc. Some of these gender differences are affected by sex hormone levels . Sex = the XY or XX status (in most cases). Ie, a child born with Denys Drash syndrome will likely need a genetic test to determine the ir sex.

Not criticizing - where did you get your definitions from? I compared a bunch of online dictionaries and an old sociology textbook I have from college to make sure I still had the right basic definition of "gender". You'll also note that in your own definition some (and therefore not "all") of these differences are affected b y sex hormones. What are we even arguing about?
lawrence It is good that a woman stands for men's right. It makes it more touching and authentic.

@Grizabeebles Gender is intrinsic. Efforts to castrate, medicate and raise boys as girls (or vice versa) simply fail, despite the best efforts of those who write wistfully in your sociology textbook. My use of the word "some" was not accidental. You were aware of your gender long before you entered puberty - and certainly before you wer e old enough to read politics dressed up as scientific definition s. Gender expressions change over time. This is true. But this culture is as much shaped by individuals expressing th eir gender as individuals are shaped by it.

So we actually agree - " Gender" includes a person's "sex" but is not limited to a person' s sexual characteristics. In regard to your comment "Efforts to castrate, medicate and raise boys as girls (or vice versa) simply fail" - I believe you are referring to the single case of David Reimer. In fact, his case only indicates th at gender cannot be related entirely to genitalia and sex hormones because removing David's gonads and providing hormone replacement therapy did not change his gender identity. If you are arguing that gender is somehow "intrinsic" (i.e. t ied to sex DNA but not ge nes for sex organs or l evels of sex hormones) then you have no grounds for the blanket claim tha t unusual gender identities cannot exist. Intersex people already exist and they exist because genetic mutations exist. The same is true for any hyp othetical "gender-related" alleles. Mutations could be - and probably are - extremely rare (i.e. intersex births are somewhere between around 0.018% and 1.7% of live births) but they would almost certainly exist. Even a comparable rate of just 0.018% would mean that there are some 134 million atypically gendered people out in the world and some 5.7 million in the United States alone. Personally, that's not enough to make me go around calling people "ze" instead of "he" or "she" but that's still a hell of a lot of people. If you are a rguing that gender is intrinsic to the human soul or something, I have no argument because you would no longer be talking about what you can prove. That said, we agree ( again) that "sex" is a part o f a person's "gender". I just think you have an uphill battle i f you believe "gender" is always going to line up with "biologically male"/"biologically female" when the biology doesn't always line up that way.

@Tathagata Did you just insinuate that gender is a social construct? If gender is a social construct then please address the following:   1) why do newborns (free from external influence) already make typica l gender choices based on the ir sex? 2) What word is there then that defines those preferences / behavior /etc., typically associated w ith sex? 3) Why does Sweden a country that has elimin ated gender for 4 decades now, women and men still do typical men and women things?

@Grizabeebels I'm not sure what you are trying to say. Could please answer this very simple question. In your opinion, how many genders are there: 2? or, potential 7 billion? If gender is >2, then what is the term that refers to actions / behavior/ preferences/ etc, usually associated with sex?

I don't (believe " gender" is always going to line up with "biologically male"/"biologically female" traits). Sorry if I gave that impression. Same with the claim that unusual gender identities cannot exist. This claim is not mine, although I tend towards the idea that there are 3 genders: "boy", "girl", and "I don't know". Where children's intrinsi c gender identities do come from, I don't know, but I don't believe it follows that a (possible) genetic basis f or gender necessarily means that only the person's hormones and sex chromosomes are involved. There is good evidence to show it comes from very early brain development in utero, but that could be a complex interplay between the mother's hormones, the child's hormones, genetics and environment. The main point being that once a child is born, t heir gender is intrinsic and cannot be changed. Another example for this, besides the tragic story of David Reimer, comes from intersex boys who were 'fixed' and raised as girls. Over half 'transitioned' back to boys despite being raised as girls. Perhaps their cases are buried in the biology section and have been banished from the annals of sociology and "gender studies"?

Mentalidade Logica & Chani J.R. My earlier statement regarding intersex people should have largely explained several of these points already. First, just as genetic and environmental factors create a whole host of intersex conditions, the same "complex interplay" could result in a wide variety of "intergender" conditions between or even outside male and female. Asking how many genders there are is like asking exactly where the color " red "> stops and the color "blue" begins in the following image: [LINK] This is what people say when they hypothesize about a "gender spectrum". I prefer to think of it a s "gender gradient". Also, many things ab out gender are cultural. There is no genetic imperative to wear pink dresses, watch romantic comedies, be a bad driver and/or mechanic, or have an endless craving to go shopping. For example bein g a "drag q>ueen" and loving the movie "The Notebook" are considered unusual male behaviour except when you are a male Scottish film critic who wears kilts. The history of fashion, for example the wearing of high heels or the fedora hat also shows that there's plenty of evidence that clothing choice is especially culture-driven a nd not gender-driven. I totally agree that many asp ects of gender could be (and probably are) determined at birth and continue to develop well into adulthood just as (or perhaps "because") our brains do. Trying to change it could very well be just as impossible as turning testes into working ovaries and would probably be just as pointless as treating dextrocardia in cases where it doesn't impair bodily function. (we did find the genes for the ovaries thing in mice though.) And in your own example about intersex boys - less than half continued identifying as female but this proves the absolute statem ent that gender "cannot be changed" incorrect otherwise all of the subjects would have transitioned male. If gender were truly were intrinsic and unchanging then no amount of family or cultural pressure would convince any of them to "stay" female. Once again, still I agree that "c orrecting" gender identity would be extremely difficult, mostly unsuccessful, probably unnecessary and of dubious help t o a child's mental health compared to simply letting the child live as whatever gender they want to live as.

" otherwise all of the subjects would have transitioned male." - they were re-transitioning. That's a very large difference - and a very large disturbance. This truly is a terribly unethical experiment we're conducting on children.

"they were re-transitioning". So gender can't change because some males changed once and other males changed twice? I still don't see how this supports your position. I agree that the experiment is unethical. And so was the Miligram experiment, Baby Albert and the Stanford Prison Experiment. We still learned a lot about human psychology in the doing though. Personally, I'm okay with agreeing never to do something that turns out horrible ever again and still use the results that came from it. How ethical the experiment was is really a re d> herring for the purposes of wheth er gender is innate and absolute.

@Chani J.R I tend to agree with your views in general. By the way, very recently, science also determine that culture can be traced to DNA. "This truly is a terribly unethical experiment we're conducting on children." > I couldn't have said better myself, hence why the recent increase in Gender Dysphoria, along with the outrageous suicides relating to it. I think it is criminal and I have no hesitation to blame feminism for it, with their one -gender or spectru m-gender ideology..

@Grizabeebles

That was a very simple question - no?
How many genders are there:
2?
or potentially 7 billion?

I had a long answer then my browser crashed so I'm going to just blurt it out and hope for the best. BTW, could you provide a link to that study linking culture and DNA? It kinda sounds like it proves the entire field of anthropology wrong. "How many genders are there?" is a loaded question - it's a bullshit tactic to make me play by your rules. The world doesn't come down into perfect little boxes for you to count and fill with stuff. You might as well be asking "How many numbers are there?" Not only are there an infinite number of numbers but each number is infinitely divisible - meaning there's an infinite number of numbers between each of the infinite number of numbers. For what its worth, I believe the vast majority of the 7.5 billion human beings alive today are considered either "male" or "female" gendered but there are hundreds of millions of exceptions just like there are hundreds of millions of people who don't technically classify as having either the male or female sex because of developmental disorders. In India and Samoa there are already accepted social groups considered "third gender" and for different reasons. Our definitions of what is "masculine" and "feminine" vary between cultures and have changed consistently over time. And they will continue to change into the future. An "effeminat e" g>ay man in India would be considered male gendered and thrown in prison. In Samoa he might be considered "fa'afafine". In the United States he'd be a male and maybe have his own reality TV show. I guess what I'm sayin g is gender is just a category we assign to people the same way we assign "genre" to movies. Whether you view it as primarily cultural or entirely part of a person's physical make-up that just means that wherever you decide to start drawing lines, its always going to be arbitrary. It can still be useful, but its still arbitrary. And that's fine.

The reason why I suggest that it would be harder for a child to re- transition is the same reason why someone who feels their gender does not align with thei r sex would n ot transition. It's a huge disruption to their existing life. The intersex children that have been mistakenly assigned "female" have already had surgery to help align their outward appearance with their assig ned gender. That alone is impossible to reverse. Surgery may be able to fashion for them a penis-looking thing, but what do you do for those who've had their testes removed? Hormones can be artificially given, but there is of course much that is still going to be missing. And that's just the physical issues. Then there are the social ones. Here it is wise to remember the difference between intri nsic gender (ie the identity you have) wit h the gender you outwardly express ( ie the gender others perceive you as). Some of these children might know that they're boys, but they carry on presenting as girls because they're coping well in a lif e where gender has nowhere near the impact that sociology textbooks would have us believe. In fact I'd think the less friends a child has, the more likely they'd be to want to re-reassign. Some of them just wouldn't want the drama.

I'd also remind you of what Fa'afafine actually means. Is not not "man in the manner of a woman" or "man with spirit of a woman"? So the 2 genders are still there. It's just the acknowledgment that the person' s gender does not align with their biologic al sex. To put it another way, the person's inner persona does not align with their biologi cal sex. Nothing in that allows for the multiple genders being proposed and enforced by certain faculties. But nor does it allow for the notion that we can control or influence a person's intr insic gender identity. Notice I'm not alluding to how they expres s that gender identity. I'm talking about the identity itself. Gender expression is the only aspect that interacts with culture. So what does all this mean back in the real world? It means that our efforts to mandate a culture that shames boys into being girls or androgynous amoebas will only result in serious pathology. Culture (at least as it per tains to gender) arises from the expr ession of gender by members within that culture. That is why it changes over time. As with all aspects of culture, some members will be more dominant, having a greater effect on that culture, and other members will feel compelled to imitate. This is not at all the same thing as a less dominant member s aying that gender is a social (or cultural) construct.

Chani J.R - "Then there are the social ones. Here it is wise to remember the difference between intrinsic gender (ie the identity you have) with the gender you outwardly express (ie th e gender others perceive you as). Some of these children might know that they're boys, but they carry on presenting as girls because they're coping well in a life whe re gender has nowhere near the impact that sociology textbooks would have us believe. " Now you're saying t hat gender is intrinsic because over half the intersex children in a study transitioned back into boys and that the children who did not transition back were voluntarily choosing to be girls be cause gender is intrinsic? That's circular reasoning my friend. It also begs the question whether or not gender is voluntary and therefore not "intrinsic" at all. Then it also equiv ocates "gender" into "i ntrinsic gender" and "the gender you express". Let me simplify th is - "the gender you expres s" is just "gender". "Intrinsic gender" is something you made up. That is of course unless you can provide evidence from scientific studies which back up a biologi cal basis for gender separate and distinct from "gender a person chooses to express" that is not specifically about a pe rson's physical sex. "I'd also remind you of what Fa'afafine actually means." Now you're equivocating again. The Fa'afafine are tr eated as a third gender within the Samoan community - they have relationships exclusively with the other genders and are treated something like a combination of the two rather than one or the other and therefore distinct . Or d>>oes mixing yellow and blue paint not make a third color where you live? While we're at it, look up "Hijra" - they are officially and legally recognized as "third gender" in Nepal, Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh. For what its worth, I'm n ot sure that changing gender roles are having a particularly positive effect on young men either. And I think its scary that the idea that the "male identity" doesn't have some immutable basis that goes all the way back to early hunter-gathers. But you are absolutely right. Culture arises from the expression of individuals (such as this very exchange) to create a shared understanding of the world. Although, that is exactly what the definition of a "social construct" is.

right.. yeah yeah. It's like you understand exactly what I was saying. You'd be great as a gender counsellor. Hey you could even teach us how to cope with Deny's Drash. Tell us all about how our learned expressions are socially constructing the gender we see in an infant with no testes.
Didn't you just spend all that time and precious effort warping the definition of everything I said?

I looked up the actual definitions and repeated them to you.  Then I looked up actual scientific articles and easily available evidence to support those definitions.  Along the way I way have also checked your arguments against Wikipedia's list of logical fallacies, and let you know when you were being intellectually dishonest, but I don't think you were even aware you were doing it.  Lord knows I never do when I screw up.

I honestly agree with you about most of your moral positions.  I just disagree with your science.

why didn't you tell me you were 12? I had no intent to confuse you. Sorry. I was speaking about observations made in the real world where gender doesn't arise from an official legal proclamation or a map. Denys Drash kids rarely live past the age of 3 so your map i s nothing more than a cape that would get torn to shreds when he jumps off your imaginary cliff.

+Grizabeebles ""How many genders are there?" is a loaded question - it's a bullshit tactic to make me play by your rules." > It is NOT a loaded question by any means. How many arms do you have, eyes, legs, genders, etc, how can this be a loaded question? Lol. Well, if you can not quantify the answer then chances are you can rationalize any and all BS. Wow, this could be a quote. ""How many numbers are there?" > The answer as you correctly pointed out is infinite - but they are STILL numbers. (Based on today's knowledge - that is). How old is the Universe? 15 Billion years old. How far is that? 15 billion light years. How long would it take to travel it? 15 billion light years and INFINITE number of generations even at the speed of light. "Our definitions of what is "masculine" and "feminine" vary between cultures and have changed consistently over time." > Negative! Anglo men don't typically show affection but by contrast Southern Euro men do. There are still both males as far a s sex and they are still both of ma le gender. The difference is called culture, that is what changes - not the gender.  "In India and Samoa there are already accepted social groups considered "t hird gender" > I don't know much about Samoa, but India has recently been heavily influenced by feminism poison, more specifically thanks to Mrs Microsoft. By the way, do you how deplorable those particula r 3rd gender people are treated in India? Literally below rats which are incidentally actually worshiped as gods. India should have just kept homosexuality decriminalized, but thanks to Western influence that was changed recentl y. No gender is not the same as genre because the lad der has NOTHING to do with sex. Now if you say that gender has nothing to do with sex, then fine I accept it, but I will ask you another question. I ask again for your simple answer, how many genders are there?

@Grizabeebles Science states that newborns (free from any influence) already make gender type decisions - period. Science also states that men and women are different at the genome level, all the way to the brain. Only a feminist or a fool thinks that such biological differences have no impact on choices/behavior/etc. Feminists want to destroy manhood by confusing  definitions for gender, by claiming tha t gender is a spectrum or th at gender should be one and the same. Sorry feminists but you can not fool Mother Nature -she has the last say on the matter. (This is why in fact we have survived as a species - thus far).

Mentalidade Logica - I try to explain gender is an imprecise term and affected by cultural differences. You say gender doesn't change, culture does. If you can't see th e blind bullshit in that I ha ve nothing to say to you. You make claims about "science" without providing reference or evidence and expect me to believe that trumps facts I can easily look up. I mean for fuck's sake, send a goddamn link! You remind me of the old people back when I still attended church who said evolution didn't exist even though they believed in natural selection. You just hate certain words and go off the deep end fighting straw "feminists" and "liberals" even when you wind up arguing against your own beliefs. It's pathetic. I'm not going to get into this with you any more. You obviously have no interest in a reasonable discussion and are just baiting me.

The definition of gender can be imprecise. Trying to categorise species can be imprecise too - but species traits or characteristics are innate. Though the "culture" of classifying species may change over time, the species traits themselves don't change over that same time. (no, I'm not a creationist). We have been placing the definition and cultural expression "cart" of gender before the "horse" o f gender itself. To further confound this, while it is true that cultur al gender expression differs among cultures and time periods, there are cert ain gender traits that do not differ. These traits relate to risk aversion, types of play, communication style, etc. These are the traits we can and do easily identify in children. This is how we know when transgendered people aren't simply cross-dressing and choosing to express a certain cultural definitio n of gender. As for the impasse in the youtube comments section. I don't usually bother, but then again I don't usually get into arguments in comments sections. You're aware that our argument centers on the definiti on of gender but you then assume (wildly - amusingly, even) that this is because I'm unaware of the definition you're using. I've pointed out multiple times that I'm talking about the same definition, but you run off in a mad huff as if you were playing a game of one-up with a Creationist. You're focusing on the 'social construct' aspects of the definition that relates to how we classify expressi ons of gender culturally. I am parsing that sentence and recognisi ng that gender is something we can express. To shorten that and tidy it up s omewhat; Gender describes the characteristics or traits that a society or culture delineates as masculine or feminine. Ie. the society or culture doesn't c reate the gender characteristics or traits. It classifies them. When speaking of broad behavioural characteristics, these characteristics themselves are innate and present from birth. Some prefer to limit their unders tanding of gender to the discussion o f "enforced gender roles". I do not, and nor does much of science. I am aware that there are some researchers seeking to show that parents' socialisation of babies is entirely respons ible for the gender differences we perceive as inborn, but those researchers have a mountain of evidence showing otherwise to overcome. The only question that remains for me is; do we define those inborn gender differences as biologi cal - and thus sex differences? And, if we do, what do we then do with those infants whose chromosomal and genital type is male, but whose other traits are characteristic of those with female chromosomes and genitalia? We (as a culture or society) cou ld invent a new gender classification akin to "man with spirit of a woman", but I'd prefer to just accept that their gender is f emale though their sex is male. Certainly, if we were to invent a new classification, that classification would be a social construct. Hopefully this has helped to illuminate the difference between social constructions and innate characteristics that I was trying to discuss. Not every social media comments exchange has to be an argument.

@Grizabeebles Gender is not "imprecise" at all in my language and it means 'traits associated with ones' genitals", that is very precise and to the point. On the other hand if as you say, gender is = "imprecise", then why the hell do we as society allow feminists (yes feminists, in schools) to use an "imprecise" ideology to screw around with Mother Nature? "You obviously have no interest in a reasonable discussion and are just baiting me." > The difference between you and I is that you like to confuse things, to debate the nuts and bolts of an issue. I find that redundant, given that I already worked out all the details in my mind, regardless of your answer, hence my question. I mean how can we talk about the details o f gender if gender might not exist at all, or it exists like the term personality? I will gladly show you links once you answer my simple question. No bait, just a simple question, one that you keep refusing to answer because you lack foundation for your arguments. How many genders are there? 0, 2 or potentially 7 billion? The bottom line is this, you should not be afraid to quantify your position as far as the numbers of genders, and if you can't quantify the number of genders, then it is all subjective. Unfortunately, one that is increasing the rate of gender dysphoria.

Chani J.R - "you then assume (wildly - amusingly, even) that this is because I'm unaware of the definition you're using ... but you run off in a mad huff as if you were playing a game of one-up with a Creationist." That is because you keep trying to muddy the issue with these "cultural gender vs intrinsic gender" arguments. I'm using the definitions I can find in the literature. You seem to be making up your own. It's like trying to ague with a tea-partier about the definition of "freedom". "Though the "culture" of classifying species may change over time, the species traits themselves don't change over that same time" Though there are several problems with that statement there are two things I'd like to point out: 1) Biological traits do change over time due to natural selection. 2) During the court of Louis XIV high heels were a prominent male status symbol, now they are exclusively a female fashion item [LINK] As culture changes, our ideas surroundin g gender change. You and Mentalidade seem to be arguing this is wrong when it is an obvious fact. Arguing that the traits which underlay our classification of anything are innate and unalterable seems ludicrous. For example, take your argument that how risk averse a person is is related to the ir gender. Can you please show me a paper comparing how risk-averse cisgender women are to transgender women rather than cisgender men? Otherwise, despite being calle d a "gender" difference, this is really a comparis on of sexual difference. "The only question that remains for me is; do we define those inborn gender differences as biological - a nd thus sex differences? And, if we do, what do we then do with those infants whose chromosomal and genital type is male, but whose other traits are characteristic of those with female chromosomes and genitalia?" As far as I'm concerned all "differences of the b ody" are sex differences. Likewise all "differences of clothing, affect, and atti tude" are gender differences. If we simply stop using the terms interchangeably, this simplifies the argument enormously. If one's sex is no longer treated as an absolute requirement for belonging to a particular gender then there is no argument whatsoever. Those born with or with out atypical sexual characteristics simply belong to whichever gender they feel most comfortable in. If in time this leads to the creation of additional gender identities I see it causing very little harm in pluralistic societies. Basically, unless Mentalidade gets their way everything will sort itself out if we just stay on the road we're already on.
So we define the gender-specific behaviour characteristics and social differences observed in neonates as "differences of the body"? That's an interesting take.

So far as I know that's how the professionals do it.  Aggression may be affected by testosterone and dopamine levels but they in turn are affected by genetics.  Traits typically associated with "male aggressiveness" are therefore sex-related and not gender-specific.  Gender-specific traits are strictly the product of socialization like the wearing of the hijab for Muslim women or the wearing of a wedding 
dress more broadly.  You don't do it because it alters your hormone levels, you do it because society tells you to.

Adios hun

I doubt this will get through to someone as evidently vacuous as you, but here goes, " hun" (and you will find that if one of us has the right to be condescending in our exchange, it certainly isn't you): Feminism is a tribalist ideology, and thus inherently at odds with egalitarianism, as all tribal perspectives are. It seeks to reinforce a social system of female protection and related hypersensitivity to female concerns, real or imagined, while drawing attention away from, minimalizing, or denying the issues regarding the poor treatment and marginalization of the majority of males. Furthermore, it takes human matters that should be approached in terms of general humanism and redefines them in accordance with the assumption that the needs of females are paramount, that a wrong inflicted on a woman is a greater outrage than anything inflicted on a man, and that attention should focus on the impact on females above all over concerns. In general conclusion, the focus is selective, the emphasis warped. Attempts by moderates and well-meaning types to "reclaim" a good name for feminism are both futile and ethically suspect. The central ideology of feminism is the supposed need to focus on female provision, a long-standing bias and non-egalitarian impulse natural to tribal humans but justified as supposed equality by the feminist worldview. Because egalitarian principles are in vogue, the façade of egalitarianism must be worn even though what feels right - the impulses, priorities and biases of the tribalist - is at odds with those supposed principles. The answer is ideology that creates justification; i.e. females are an oppressed class and males a privileged one, thus egalitarianism means overwhelming female focus and aid.The core concept in feminist discourse is "Patriarchy" or worse "T he Patriarchy", a term that feminists misuse in a sense that has nothing to do with the word's actual meaning. Femin ist "patriarchy" is code for "the supposed (but non-existent) privileged ruling caste of the supposedly unified male tribe, that benefits males collectively at the expense of females". Which of cours e has nothing to d o with patriarchy, the social system wherein familial leadership, authority, responsibility and headship is invested in the paternal figure. Society should rightly be considered in terms of the politicized groups that hold sway over it and its narratives - a) the apex male power structure, political, academic, economical, and b) the collective of females, who are the social and foundational core. The third group is the majority of males, who form a utilitarian framework in service to these first two groups, and do not enter into political consideration. The apex male power elite and the collective of politicized females: society is essentially an uneasy and mutually exploitative, yet mutually symbiotic relationship between these two power blocs. Utilitarian males, the majority of males, only enter into political or social consideration when they are a) useful or b) threatening to the social order as consists of the first two groups. Otherwise they are neglected. Becoming friendly with tribalist structures like feminism will not change this, it will simply make it easier for the abuses to go unchallenged. Feminism reinforces the attitude of neglect, exploitation and demonization of lower-status males and closes the door on positive change and inclusivity. It is an impediment to social progress, a roadblock on the path to societal healing, and it exacerbates the problems it does not directly cause. Feminism - as the very name in conjunction with its claim to supposed egalitarianism indicates - is built on an assumption that males everywhere are part of an overarching entrenched system of selfish benefit and privilege - "the Patriarchy". To the point that movements and efforts to assist men and boys in dire straits are rejected and attacked by feminists and their supporters because they're seen as defending a supposed cabal of privileged power-holders. That is, we can see the justification used to maintain the façade of egalitarianism over the tribal impulses to privilege the comfort, protection and provision of the female and disenfranchise the competitor males who might topple the apex, established males. This is all preconscious most of the time, but it's defence of this exploitative social structure that motivates the ideologies and behaviours of the majority. This choke-hold causes misery, anger and bitterness in the utilitarian male population in general, causing further division and social breakdown. A male who is not a part of one's immediate tribe is a utility at best - and you don't empathise with your labour tools, your swords and shields - or a threat at worst. Feminists hate any structure that is seen as giving males any sort of advantage or power, which is pretty much anything that benefits any individual males in any way, since their worldview depends on the traditional idea of female vulnerability and irresponsibility, and male agency, potency and power, combined with a projected assumption of male in-group bias. Hence their understanding of a supposed conflict against a potent foe whose grip on the world must be loosened. Some might say that feminism can perhaps be summarized as the sudden (culturally speaking) belief that the male sphere needs to be colonized by the female to address a supposed imbalance, while the advantages and privileges of the female sphere remain untouched, intact, and jealously defended. (Also mostly denied, for reasons both of political convenience and deeper psychology). Once again, it's best to understand feminism as a one-sided tribal power-struggle between the formerly complimentary spheres of male and female. Feminism, then, is a tribal movement in two simultaneous ways: it stems from and reinforces the traditional tribal structure of sheltered female "objects" and utilitarian male "agents", and it reimagines females themselves as a distinct tribe in conflict with an overbearing aggressor male tribe - in part a simultaneous extrapolation from, and projection onto males of, female in-group gender bias. The tribal outgroup is the supposed (in fact non-existent) "tribe of males" - co de-named "Patriarchy" (or "The" Patriarchy), an inherent misuse of the word. This outgroup is considered to hold morally indefensible power over the in-group. Feminism, quite simply, is the pursuit of resources, power, societal status, protection or any other positive for members of the female tribe, through any means - negotiation, attack, manipulation/deception, etc. Exceptions and exemptions, opportunities and license. Sometimes what they want is legitimate and defensible, other times it isn't. But the purpose is always the perceived betterment of the "female tribe" at the expense of any other concern (be that concern balance, fairness, social stability, men, children, reason...). At its core (and I would challenge anyone to demonstrate a feminist action or behaviour at odds with this principle, whereas one can easily discredit such erroneous definitions as "equality" by showing how many feminist behaviours and initiatives conflict with them), Feminism is the lobbying for that which is currently perceived, in any given context, as bettering or furthering the interests of women who polit icize their woman-ness. That is feminism. Contrary to the feminist narrative of oppression and wrongs committed by other tribes, the women-as-women have always had tremendous power socially and morally, more so than most males can conceive of. It is this to which feminism owes its success. The "female tribe" defends what it has, and it reaches always for more. This is its imperative, as with any such group. On top of this, feminism not only continues the age-old tribalist tendency for non-apex males to enter into political consideration only in terms of a) their exploitable utility or b) the threat they pose, but it has united the two, because it exploits them as potential threats - the feminist threat narratives against men, at least the outliers.

replies.commentText: @Sambit Nayak We are born in a society where marriage is treated as sacrosanct, something which was fixed in heaven. It is a relationship valid not only in this life but also in lives yet to come. Nevertheless, this relationship is changing and law has played a very important role in altering this relationship. The legislature drafted these laws to protect the vulnerable women in the relationship, but while doing that didn't keep in consideration abuse of these laws by not so vulnerable women. The judiciary, while sympathizing with the tears of women, didn't recognize the fact that these may be crocodile tears. Due to these reasons these laws has become a tool to harass husbands, extort money from husbands and their family, to torture hapless women of the husbands family. In short, these laws have made marriage more a legal relationship than a social relationship. The law presumes, everybody knows laws. Marriage is a voluntary relationship, in the sense that till this point of time there is no law which can compel a man to marry (although in practice some women have compel men to marry them by leveling false allegation of rape against them. The recent case of suicide by an ex-Army officer is a cse in point where the man committed suicide due to pressure to marriage and in case of denial threat of false cases.). Thus every man must know the legal provisions before he enters into the legal relationship of marriage. If he enters without knowing these provisions, he cannot blame any other persons for that. However, it is the duty of legal practitioners and social workers to make tem aware of these laws so that nobody enters into a legal relationship of marriage without knowing its implications. Slowly and steadily the number of law governing the relationship between husband and wife is increasing. One thing is common in all laws- they are prejudiced and biased against the men in the sense that they give rights only to the wives and imposes duties only to the husband. Further the language of the law is such that it facilitates abuse of these laws against the husband and his family members. And in fact also the wives are systematically abusing these laws. These laws were primarily designed to protect the vulnerable women in our society but the working of these laws suggest that they have become more a weapon of harassment and extortion in the hand of not so vulnerable women. The Hindu Marriage Act and the Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act impose a duty upon the husband to maintain their wife. However a person can claim maintenance only if he/she is not able to maintain himself/herself. The term is ability or potential to maintain and not mere inability to maintain at any point of time. However, a survey of the judgments will clearly shows that even when the wife was able bodies and educated then also the courts have granted maintenance. Further, these two Acts are not sufficient and the Criminal Court is empowered to grant maintenance as per section 125 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. More Acts for the same relief means that the wife has more avenues to harass a husband through the process of Court. We can see that a wife has a right to maintenance- but what is her duty. Law say s nothing. If she abuses the husband, then also she can claim maintenance. If she beats her mother-in-law, then also she can claim maintenance. Thus a wife has no duty, only rights. Just maintenance is not something to be very worried about. What is more important that the wife has been given power to send the husband and his family members to the prison at wish? Under section 498A of t he Indian Penal Code a wife can complain that she has been treated with cruelty for dowry and name anybody in the relatives of the husband. What is cruelty or what is dow ry, nobody knows. A gift to husband is dowry but a gift to wife is streedhan. A husband should not demand any consideration for marriage, but a girl has a right to look for a wealthy husband wi th a fat pay packet; it is not dowry, it is pragmatism. The law says giving dowry is as criminal as taking dowry, the wife screams that she has given dowry, but the law does not take any action against her- this is women empowerment. Under this Section octogenarian grand mom of husbands are being prosecuted for harassment- this is power of wife. Just these are not sufficient. If your wife commits suicide, invariably you will be prosecuted under Section 304B of the IPC. Here, even the prosecution has not prove many thing, Section 113A is there in the Evidence Act to presume your guilt. When men commit suicide, the law is silent. After all men can commit suicide for so many reasons- wife can commit suicide only after harassment by husband and his family. So what, the suicide statistics shows that more men commit suicide. Once any of these cases are registered against you few things are certain-like you are likely to loose your job. You will be merely suspended if you are in government service. You will spend a couple of months in jail before the bail. In jail too you will have full company of your family members. Finally, you will be granted bail and the trial begins. What will happen in trial, I don't know. Indian Criminal Justice system is totally biased against the accused. That is why making allegation in India has become an industry. It is a tool of legal extortion in the hand of police and false accusers. Well, the purpose of this article is merely informing the worse half of the population the legal consequence of marriage and their vulnerably, if they decide to marry. Difficult to imagine-even now men marry. In any case old habits die hard. There is no solution. We are living in Rule of Law and when the law is tyrannical and prejudiced, you cannot have a solution. But, the risk can be reduced by taking recourse to written contract at the time of marriage. It is a good idea to enter into written contract at the time of marriage with your would be wife. No law prohibits such type of contract. The contract can make provisions for expenses of marriage ceremony, list of gifts received, the couple decision regarding maintenance, child custody and all other items, which the couple feels necessary to incorporate in the written contract. It may seem nauseating to introduce the idea of contract in marriage, but it is better as law has already entered into marriage. Written contract is just one mutually agreed way to reduce the rigor of falsehood in deposition before the court. It is better to catch up a lawyer before the police catch up with you. Show less

I can agree that this talk makes legitimate points, but I have a single question: 
If you look at the statistics, in 2012, a total of 661 cases of rape were registered. Acquittal rate: 46%, i.e 304 resulted in acquittal. The next year, data was only available till August, which is over half the year. 318 cases were registered (less than half of the last year) and 237 acquittals were given, which lands us at a total of 75% of acquittals. So in over half the year, the number of rape cases registered fell, the acquittal rates rose, laws were changed to be made stricter after Nirbhaya (that's what Ms. Bhardwaj meant, I believe?), and yet those stricter laws led to higher acquittals. I don't understand this connection. Shouldn't tougher laws have meant more cases registered overall and lower acquittals?

Additionally, I agree that the laws should be changed to support both genders. Obviously, men need legal recourse in cases of false accusations and dowry violence too. Our long winded court system and unusual lack of investigation for confirmation can drive people to insane lengths. If we as women can't support that, we should at least support it for the simple fact that the more issues we have with people abusing the legal system, the more likely it is that necessary laws such as making marital rape a punishable offence will never see the light of day, simply because our judiciary system is too afraid of these laws being abused.

It is important to understand that women too can be sociopaths/psychopaths, like many of the men. As for the current situation, when I am at a public place or even at work place, I fear women. I try not to look at them. When I talk I try to keep things to a minimum, avoid courtesy and never joke. I fear women and I am very young now. I remember when lining up at a bank, I moved quickly to get an empty spot and a woman also tried to get there but I was faster so, I got there first. The woman created a ruckus as per how "I treated my sister and mother" and the guard intervened to put me at the end of another line. I am an introvert, I rarely talk to strangers and I think a 100 times before I take any action and I am 100% sure, I never even looked at tha t woman. But, people present there laughed at my "sanskar". I felt humiliated and stopped my tears. But, that is part of life I am fully aware of now. Wherever I go now, I try to keep a good distance with a ny woman. Sometimes, I have left my change at shops when there are female cashiers. And I think it is correct because I prefer losing some money than accepting the possibility of being humiliated for no reason.

Beware of marriage! We are born in a society where marriage is treated as sacrosanct, something which was fixed in heaven. It is a relationship valid not only in this life but also in lives yet to come. Nevertheless, this relationship is changing and law has played a very important role in altering this relationship. The legislature drafted these laws to protect the vulnerable women in the relationship, but while doing that didn't keep in consideration abuse of these laws by not so vulnerable women. The judiciary, while sympathizing with the tears of women, didn't recognize the fact that these may be crocodile tears. Due to these reasons these laws has become a tool to harass husbands, extort money from husbands and their family, to torture hapless women of the husbands family. In short, these laws have made marriage more a legal relationship than a social relationship. The law presumes, everybody knows laws. Marriage is a voluntary relationship, in the sense that till this point of time there is no law which can compel a man to marry (although in practice some women have compel men to marry them by leveling false allegation of rape against them. The recent case of suicide by an ex-Army officer is a cse in point where the man committed suicide due to pressure to marriage and in case of denial threat of false cases.). Thus every man must know the legal provisions before he enters into the legal relationship of marriage. If he enters without knowing these provisions, he cannot blame any other persons for that. However, it is the duty of legal practitioners and social workers to make tem aware of these laws so that nobody enters into a legal relationship of marriage without knowing its implications. Slowly and steadily the number of law governing the relationship between husband and wife is increasing. One thing is common in all laws- they are prejudiced and biased against the men in the sense that they give rights only to the wives and imposes duties only to the husband. Further the language of the law is such that it facilitates abuse of these laws against the husband and his family members. And in fact also the wives are systematically abusing these laws. These laws were primarily designed to protect the vulnerable women in our society but the working of these laws suggest that they have become more a weapon of harassment and extortion in the hand of not so vulnerable women. The Hindu Marriage Act and the Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act impose a duty upon the husband to maintain their wife. However a person can claim maintenance only if he/she is not able to maintain himself/herself. The term is ability or potential to maintain and not mere inability to maintain at any point of time. However, a survey of the judgments will clearly shows that even when the wife was able bodies and educated then also the courts have granted maintenance. Further, these two Acts are not sufficient and the Criminal Court is empowered to grant maintenance as per section 125 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. More Acts for the same relief means that the wife has more avenues to harass a husband through the process of Court. We can see that a wife has a right to maintenance- but what is her duty. Law say s nothing. If she abuses the husband, then also she can claim maintenance. If she beats her mother-in-law, then also she can claim maintenance. Thus a wife has no duty, only rights. Just maintenance is not something to be very worried about. What is more important that the wife has been given power to send the husband and his family members to the prison at wish? Under section 498A of t he Indian Penal Code a wife can complain that she has been treated with cruelty for dowry and name anybody in the relatives of the husband. What is cruelty or what is dow ry, nobody knows. A gift to husband is dowry but a gift to wife is streedhan. A husband should not demand any consideration for marriage, but a girl has a right to look for a wealthy husband wi th a fat pay packet; it is not dowry, it is pragmatism. The law says giving dowry is as criminal as taking dowry, the wife screams that she has given dowry, but the law does not take any action against her- this is women empowerment. Under this Section octogenarian grand mom of husbands are being prosecuted for harassment- this is power of wife. Just these are not sufficient. If your wife commits suicide, invariably you will be prosecuted under Section 304B of the IPC. Here, even the prosecution has not prove many thing, Section 113A is there in the Evidence Act to presume your guilt. When men commit suicide, the law is silent. After all men can commit suicide for so many reasons- wife can commit suicide only after harassment by husband and his family. So what, the suicide statistics shows that more men commit suicide. Once any of these cases are registered against you few things are certain-like you are likely to loose your job. You will be merely suspended if you are in government service. You will spend a couple of months in jail before the bail. In jail too you will have full company of your family members. Finally, you will be granted bail and the trial begins. What will happen in trial, I don't know. Indian Criminal Justice system is totally biased against the accused. That is why making allegation in India has become an industry. It is a tool of legal extortion in the hand of police and false accusers. Well, the purpose of this article is merely informing the worse half of the population the legal consequence of marriage and their vulnerably, if they decide to marry. Difficult to imagine-even now men marry. In any case old habits die hard. There is no solution. We are living in Rule of Law and when the law is tyrannical and prejudiced, you cannot have a solution. But, the risk can be reduced by taking recourse to written contract at the time of marriage. It is a good idea to enter into written contract at the time of marriage with your would be wife. No law prohibits such type of contract. The contract can make provisions for expenses of marriage ceremony, list of gifts received, the couple decision regarding maintenance, child custody and all other items, which the couple feels necessary to incorporate in the written contract. It may seem nauseating to introduce the idea of contract in marriage, but it is better as law has already entered into marriage. Written contract is just one mutually agreed way to reduce the rigor of falsehood in deposition before the court. It is better to catch up a lawyer before the police catch up with you.

Misandric bills had a history of becoming laws in India and going unchallenged. When MRM burst into the scene some 10 years ago in its primitive stage, we didn't have a fast internet connection to vent out our anger on YouTube. So we started concentrating on laws and activism. It has begun fruition these days. Only recently protests from MRAs prevented the passing of a bill called Irretrievable Breakdown of Marriage or IrBM. The bill proposed that in the wake of a divorce the wife was to get 50% of the husbands property and upto 25% of the Father-in-Laws property no questions asked. MRAs took to the streets, flooded the social media and most importantly started meeting Members of Indian Parliament (MPs). (The terms used here are identical to that in British politics). But not just that we ran a detailed SMS and e-Mailing campaign against the bill. We were covering the discussion live on Facebook and Twitter which the bill was under actual discussion in the Upper House, Rajya Sabha (analogous to House of the Lords). We did so because unlike feminists we didn't hav e a 100 year old or any lobby inside the Parliament. So we were forced to lead the offence from outside. We took to the streets. Hell I was there too. Had me a Megaphone and everything. We picketed outside the Parliament constantly. And now the bill has begun to be retracted. The thing here is, we have devised a way to systematically challenge specific laws that were previously going unchallenged. So the college was introduced to Men's Movement during my time. Now the new kids know what it is. These kinds of social changes put feminists in a fix. Women have suffered enough, still are suffering just look at nayana pujari case, nirbhaya case etc. just because some laws are misused sometimes in sparingly rare cases does not mean they should be repealed, laws are misused worldwide; we need to cleanse and make sure there's proper implementation rather than repealing these laws. And excuse me lady, get your facts checked - when you talk about women you have to give 'evidence'; don't trot around saying 'when you talk about men you have to give evidence' and make such baseless, futile and ignorant statements. If that were the case the accused in Jessica Lal case, Priyadarshini Mattoo case, Ruchika Girhotra Case, Riju Bafna case all would be convicted/acquitted at the first instance without even recording/examining/assailing evidence which has NOT been the case at all. To make such statements would be making a mockery of the Judiciary and Democracy. Take a look at [LINK] for true statistics. Also, Section 2 (q) of the Domestic Violence Act, 2005 has been made gender neutral as recently adjudicated by the Supreme Court i.e. by Justices Kurian Joseph, Rohinton Nariman in Hiral Hirsora v Kusum Hirsora in Civil Appeal 10084 of 2016 decided on 6th October, 2016. Be very careful while quoting examples as the law is ever dynamic and always evolving, don't make wrong and misleading statements just because you have a platform and a mike in your hand. I'm all for gender neutral laws and punishments to be levied in case of false complaints but while making sweeping statements like 'h >o >ho ho, women's issues don't require evidence' don't be condescending and don't be stupid. In a democracy all offences in order to be proved or disproved require evidence and a proper trial. Also, we are conveniently forgetting that MARITAL RAPE is still not a crime in India, as was held even in Britain in R v R (1991) in fact the current law ALLOWS marital rape. Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code, 1 860 -'Sexual intercou rse or sexual acts by a man with his own wife, the wife not being under fifteen y ears of age, is not rape.' India has the world's highest number of early marriages and while fewer girls younger than 15 are being married (18.2 percent), the rates for girls ages 15-18 has increased to 29.2 percent. Waiting a year eliminates 'rape.' The guidelines on preve ntion of sexual harassment of women at the workplace were laid down by the Supreme Court in 1997 (yes that's right, in '97 after 50 years of INDEPENDENCE there were no laws in place to protect w omen from sexual harassment at workplace) in Vishakha and Ors. v State of Rajasthan (read about the case here- [LINK] ; [LINK] and the law i.e. The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013 regarding the same was laid down in 2013 (AFTER 16 goddamn years). Not to forget men constantly shoving, pushing, groping, ogling, pinching parts, leering us everywhere and anywhere right from the streets to railway platforms to buses to workplaces. According to the National Crime Records Bureau 2013 annual report, 24,923 rape cases were reported across India in 2012. Out of these, 24,470 were committed by someone known to the victim (98% of the cases). Fight for issues faced by women as well then, i f you're so gender neutral also, update your facts and figures. Just because you have a stage and a microphone you do not have the right to stand there and mock women's rights and issues. Check your privilege AND your facts before you open your mouth anywhere.

replies.commentText: @Joachim Eriksson Why are laws to protect women important? I mean more important than a law to protect any human being? Laws should seek to protect the accused, not just the accuser. A person falsely accused of a crime is also a victim.
@Manhood Academy We are not talking about 1st world country here so please don't do this.
Dowry laws are similar to rape laws around the world. So...

Well they aren't taken prima facie and you cannot drag a grandparents who are bedridden, kids [2 month old baby], relatives who don't live there, people who aren't present there nor dogs. [Yes even a dog is arrested for dowry law case]

The rape laws are worse. If you refuse to marry a woman, she can accuse you of rape. And even powerful politician's sons can become targets, so what do you think the chances of middle-class men like me are?

@Zubin Darbari False accusations should lead to imprisonment.
I agree but no strict law is passed because no one wants to be tagged anti women.

@alienzen "A person falsely accused of a crime is also a victim."
Actually, the person being falsely accused is the only victim in such a case - the false accuser is the criminal.

False accusers, once proven to be such, should be sentenced to serve the same tariff which the falsely accused would have served, had he been found guilty.

In the case of false accusations of rape the impact is even greater, as there exist "rape shield" laws in many countries preventing the accusers' identities from being publicised, while no such protection is given to the (falsely) accused - and his reputation and chance of normal life are immediately destroyed, before ever going to trial. He can even lose his life, through the actions of vigilante justice.
What would be an appropriate sentence for such a false accuser?
(The only sensible action is to extend such "rape shield" laws to both accuser and accused, with publication of the guilty party only after sentencing.)
